speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Welcome to Contextualizing Feminist Voices, Teaching with the Global Feminisms Project.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: This series is focused on teaching, pedagogy, and uses of the archive in the context of the classroom.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Designed with a special emphasis on educators, in each episode you will learn from instructors

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: who have used the project's interviews in their courses, and about activities and resources

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: for incorporating the archive into your class.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Today we will be joined by Dr. Janaya Lasker-Freddy, who currently serves as coordinator of second

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: year Italian courses in the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures at the University

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: of Michigan.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: She has published on women in

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: futurism and her current scholarly interests include language, pedagogy, oral history,

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: and comics. Janaya holds a PhD in Italian studies from the University of California at Berkeley.

speaker: SPEAKER_00
text: Thank you so much for joining us today. I wanted to start by asking you,

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: could you briefly describe the course that you use the archive in?

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Of course, and thank you for having me. So the course that I am teaching and I'm using the

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: interviews in is Italian 232, which is the fourth semester of the language requirement

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: here at the University of Michigan. We have a language requirement in LS&A, which so students take four semesters of a language. And so this is their very

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: last language course of the requirement. Thank you for sharing. And how do you use the material

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: in the archive in this course? So since it's 232 and it's typically a coordinated section,

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: we have certain grammar structures that we need to absolutely study in this course.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: So usually we have a grammar textbook.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: And in this grammar textbook, typically you would have a lot of cultural readings or literary readings.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: And basically what I've done is I've just gutted that and taken all of that out.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: And instead I've used the interviews from the archive as the cultural content of the course.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: So therefore, everything we do culturally is related to the interviews.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: That's a really innovative approach.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: It seems like you're really redesigning elementary language learning.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: And what do you think is most effective about the way you use the global feminism as materials? I think it's effective to just make it the focus of the

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: entire course. So I should say that I have been using, we listen to two full interviews. So the

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: interviews that we have been listening to, probably each one is around 45 minutes to an hour. And then

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: you know, I break it up into kind of 15 minute sections.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Everything's divided into chapters and they do five chapters. So they're still doing their grammar,

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: but for their content, they have to listen to two parts of the interview. And we do it,

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: of course, at the same time, but they prepare by, you know, I created Quizlet, which is a way to learn vocabulary. And I take the words from the interview to prepare them to study. And I also

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: alternate the way in which they consume the interview. So for example, if there are four

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: parts, you're going to have to watch two of those parts, and then they read two of those parts.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: So it goes watching it, reading it, watching or reading it, just to develop the different skills

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: of listening and also reading.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: So I think it's effective because that becomes the sole focus of our work culturally.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: And then too, within these interviews, we can also find a plethora of examples of the grammar structures that they are studying.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: So the two go hand in hand because we can always use that, the text, to look more closely at language.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: Fantastic. And which interviewees are you featuring?

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Yes, so I am using the interview by Michela Murgia, who is a famous feminist in Italy, and she comes from Sardinia.

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: And also I'm using the interview of Valentina Colletta, who is a trans activist. And so one thing that impairing

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: these two, using these two as the major focus of the course, it's been surprising how much

speaker: SPEAKER_01
text: regional culture comes out of these two interviews. So for example, in the interview of Miquela Morcha,

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: she talks about how she has this elective family, which is a traditional Sardinian custom

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: that is now no longer used,

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: but she chose to be in a part of another family.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: And so this cultural idea is very much rooted

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: in Sardinian culture.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: she was born intersex and is trans

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: and is a trans activist.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: And she says that her childhood was so happy

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: and that she was pretty much accepted,

text: at least by the adults around her, because in Naples, which is the closest major city to where

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: she grew up, there's this historical figure of the feminello, which is kind of like a third gender

text: and is seen in Neapolitan culture as to bring good luck and it's very accepted and so therefore these regional

text: to be able to address things

text: I find like main topics

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: on these topics. So they get to choose, but they're all coming from the interview,

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: the interviews themselves. So that's a way to kind of like be able to enhance if you can't address

text: you can't get to in a regular course. Yeah, I think that

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: Yes, thanks. So because we really do have to do a balancing act between language and content and culture and grammar, it is the sole cultural focus of our course, but we can't spend every single day going in-depth into the material.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: So, for example, on days in which we discuss the interviews, I really kind of try to have them come up with the themes.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
text: to further reinforce them. But it remains a little bit superficial because we're not spending
